WRITING.TITLE: How drunk was tom during the reunion tour?
WRITING.TEXT: Not trying to steal focus from the new album or dig up past issues, but obviously with the new album I'm on a bit of Blink kick, which naturally includes a lot of Thomas DeLonge songs. So my question is: how drunk was Tom during the reunion tour? I ask mainly because I watch videos of the reunion tour and he seems so on. He was playing really well and he was funny as always, but actually seemed to want to be there. Yet I always hear he was wasted every show. Is that really true? I can't seem to find many articles about it. And if it is, does anyone know why he felt the need to do that every show? Seems kinda disrespectful. Did he ever get over that or is he just like that every time he plays live (which is basically just with Blink)? Kinda puts a damper on those reunion videos, cause he really seems like he's having a lot of fun, and I'd like to think its not just alcohol.

WRITING.TITLE: Is Transvestite the ultimate blink-182 song?
WRITING.TEXT: I would argue that these guys got it right on the money straight from the beginning. And its not even widely available these days! But seriously, Transvestite is both of the guys, hysterical, but also a great song with a fantastic build. It never gets old to me and kind of the first song I think of when I think pure Blink, as opposed to the later more polished mainstream Enema and Take Off stuff. If there's anyone that for some reason hasn't heard this, you need to, NOW: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2j81XXtx5PI

WRITING.TITLE: mark interviewing angels and airwaves
WRITING.TEXT: What are people's thoughts on this? I've seen it before but I go back to it often cause I just find it so fascinating. I'm probably naive, but Mark and Tom seem totally fine here. But that can't possibly be the case right? Mark must be at least a little peeved that Tom was promoing all this stuff at the same time as Neighborhoods, and the thing that basically held Neighborhoods up for so long. I didn't think their relationship was on good terms by this point but they seem so cordial here. Enough to fool me. I guess cause its AVA it seems so shocking to me, although mature. Interview - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FcRCDUuS8Mc Bonus - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-BbM4TZjunI

WRITING.TITLE: they should bring back the acoustic sets from australia
WRITING.TEXT: I know it was done because Travis wasn't there (I assume?) and it would be more bittersweet now without Tom there (cause I loved just seeing him and Mark with acoustic guitars), but those were awesome. Provided a great spot for rarities and it felt so god damn fresh. I would kill to see these: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RnAcLR8T_DE

WRITING.TITLE: blew it big time with a tOYPAJ vinyl
WRITING.TEXT: Earlier tonight I found a vinyl for TOYPAJ for a mere $55 on Ebay. Included all three of the singles too, which is why I'd even want the thing! The whole thing seemed weird to me, as they usually run like $25-$30 more than that, and this was Buy It Now AND Free Shipping. Almost too good to be true that it threw me off. Kinda waited on it a bit then figured "what the hell, this'll be great". By that point, it had already been bought, and I figured it would go fast. FUCK! Still shocked at how cheap it is. That is rare right? I mentioned it to someone else tonight and they were like "couldn't you just find it in a store?" and I said I'd never seen one other than Ebay. Here's a link to the listing: http://www.ebay.com/itm/BLINK-182-TAKE-OFF-YOUR-PANTS-AND-JACKET-WHITE-VINYL-LP-3X7-/222172692868?hash=item33ba864184%3Ag%3ABE8AAOSwkl5Xdh3~ amp;nma=true amp;si=QYdLgToSZ6bRLDWPC%252F8bDnbZn2Y%253D amp;orig_cvip=true amp;rt=nc amp;_trksid=p2047675.l2557 Was the lucky bastard anyone here lol? Damn, it still kills me that I didn't jump sooner. Would have loved it since its my favorite album. Anyway, just wanted to get that off my chest before I get to sleep. Guess I now gotta check more often as I don't know when one that low will get posted again!

WRITING.TITLE: What is the difference between Start The Machine and The Machine
WRITING.TEXT: Just downloaded the supposed bonus track on We Don't Need To Whisper called The Machine, and when I listened it seemed the lyrics were identical to Start The Machine. A bit different instrumentation I think, but is there any real difference between the two songs? Seems the biggest thing is Start The Machine has the extra verse at the end about "if love's a word that you say..." but otherwise its the same. Seemed curious to me.

WRITING.TITLE: "Enthused" and "Apple Shampoo" - the ultimate defiant tom and mark songs?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm figuring out how to quite phrase the question, but I've always thought when I listen to Dude Ranch those songs seem like pretty defiant statements from these two, essentially, kids about to and trying to take over the world. Does anyone else hear this? I just love their placement in the album, almost side by side, and just feel each one speaks so clearly them. Enthused - I LOVE that buildup to Tom's vocals. It almost seems like it might be an instrumental track then you get that defiant strong guitar strum leading up to Tom's angsty "Am I strung out? Crazy, or not allowed..." I'm not quite sure what he's railing against, but I feel its just so genuinely Tom's feelings at the moment mixed with some great music. Apple Shampoo - a similar thing here where its almost pure Mark (and Enthused pure Tom) just venting about life and where to go. "both getting tired of punk rock clubs, and both playing in punk rock bands." Just such a statement of being at a crossroads. I don't know, maybe I'm insane. But I've always seen these two as the deep cuts that perfectly work together and speak to their respective values. Love their placement on the album and love the defiant nature they seem to have about them. Does anyone else hear it, has anyone else ever thought that, or am I just strung out and crazy?

WRITING.TITLE: WTF!!! Where is She's Out Of Her Mind?!!! Are you friggen kidding me mark???!!
WRITING.TEXT: I'm not actually furious, but seriously, I kinda am. How the hell aren't you playing the best song on the album? I'd also throw Rabbit Hole in for Los Angeles, but thats a more minor concern.

WRITING.TITLE: Do you think Travis is the reason more pre-enema songs don't get played?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm sure its not, but has Travis ever talked about this? Does he feel uncomfortable playing songs that he didn't originally record and now that they have 3 huge albums with Trav they tend to avoid them? And also why they go towards Wendy Clear and Dysentery Gary as obscure cuts as opposed to Dude Ranch songs? Just all thoughts I've been pondering. I love Enema, TOYPAJ and self titled as much as the next guy, but how many times can we hear those same songs.

WRITING.TITLE: So how long was this album really brewing?
WRITING.TEXT: Here's why I ask: So Tom leaves (or gets fired) in January 2015. He releases a CD of demos 4 months later that includes the song Golden Showers In The Golden State. Now, it can't just be perfectly coincidental that the song is a childish ode to the very state our newest CD is all about. Even Tom said some of these songs were planned for Blink, so obviously by the time Tom left Blink must have already decided on the California theme of the next album, a full year and a half before it comes out. I just found that interesting. I wonder when they originally planned for the new album to come out (maybe summer 2015?). Did Tom write any other songs in keeping with the California theme? Are they on To The Stars? IMO I'm almost angry that Tom even had anything to do with the album. Not cause I don't like him, but I just then think about what he would have added. The fact that something Golden Showers exists makes me want to hear this album done with him. Regardless of what people think of the song's lyrics, the music is pure Blink. I don't know, I just kinda wish they had come up with the idea after he left or done something completely new after recruiting Skiba. Cause since its inception was around with Tom I keep thinking "what if?" Anyone else? It also just surprises me this album took almost 2 years to make. They talk about it being fast, but obviously it was planned as early as winter of 2014.

WRITING.TITLE: Would anyone else love to see Tom do a solo tour?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm genuinely not sure whether this is the right place to post this or extremely obvious, but does anyone else feel this way? Just listening to the Demos disc right now and I really do think there are some good songs there. Maybe nothing too deep or long lasting, but I don't see a problem with New World and Suburban Kings, and I was just thinking "will we ever see those live in any form?" And then I thought "it would be awesome if Tom went out and did a solo tour". He's got so much music with so many different bands that I think that would be a really cool and fresh show. He wouldn't have to restrict himself to just playing one thing, he could just embrace his catalogue. Play Box Car, play some solo stuff, play AVA, obviously play Blink material. But I think it could be really cool. Play intimate venues, get a list of about 50 songs worked up you'd want to pull out, and just go out and do your thing. Not really sure who the band would be. Hard not to imagine David on guitar who I think would be right, and Brooks would be cool on drums (since he's been solo and Blink), but I'd be fine with Atom or Ilan too. But I just think that would be a lot of fun. Focus on your centric Blink songs, well known and deep cuts, and just have a blast. I think you could easily make a 25 song setlist of just Tom's Blink and other material. TL;DR: the question posed at the title of the thread.

WRITING.TITLE: Check for ticket upgrades (Brooklyn, NY just had one)
WRITING.TEXT: Not sure if this is happening everywhere, but I was just able to upgrade my Brooklyn tickets for next week to seats right next to the stage! I have to imagine they are VIP packages that just didn't sell. But Ticketmaster had no issues exchanging/upgrading, so if anyone is sitting in the lower bowl for that price (or upper and wants to get closer), there are now two rows of tickets on both Mark and Matt's side. So stoked to catch this drop!

WRITING.TITLE: Finally saw Blink for the first time tonight. A few thoughts:
WRITING.TEXT: Overall, I thought it was a very good show. I feel any negatives weren't really their fault. My biggest negative was I thought the sound wasn't that great. Maybe its because I was on Mark's side, but it just seemed way too muddy and it was hard to hear Matt most times, and vocals in general. Good setlist. I'd never seen them before so obviously I don't have the benefit of knowing the real difference without Tom there, but it started off sorta weird. Not weird, but the first 4 songs or so being so Mark heavy, even taking the mic center stage for What's My Age Again really seemed to solidify that they are making a stand. By the end I noticed it less because it was a fairly even split, but at the beginning it seemed noticeable. Surprisingly, two of my favorite performances were Down and I Miss You, which I think they just killed, and those are two I rarely listen to these days. Lots of new stuff which was nice and disappointing in the same way. We got like 8 songs which seemed way more than usual, and while I like that they are pushing it I wish they were playing more of my favorites from it. I'd definitely include She's Out Of Her Mind and Rabbit Hole for others. Cynical I thought was great. Reckless Abandon was awesome, as was Violence and Dysentery Gary. Los Angeles was a weird main set closer and I'm not sure why that was switched with Carousel since I believe that was a first this whole tour. Overall, a really solid show. Probably a 7 or 8 out of 10. I could say more but then this is gonna get really long. I thought Skiba absolutely destroyed in places and in others Tom was sorely missed. Also, I have read nothing but "Skiba has low energy and doesn't move at all" since this tour began. Maybe tonight was different, and I know he doesn't have as much energy as Mark (who does) but Skiba was all over the place tonight. It was awesome.

WRITING.TITLE: With the lack of banter, it pretty much is a different band
WRITING.TEXT: Let me preface, but saying I love the players in this band, and while I love Tom I don't agree with what he did and how he conducted himself post reunion. But I gotta be honest, tonight at Barclays, I saw a different band. A different band than has been Blink for 20 years. I get that the banter isn't everyone's cup of tea (I have met people here that have said the live album doesn't really do it for them) But this is just such a left turn from what we've always known. Blink ALWAYS talked in between every song. Tonight, I legitimately think they said less than two minutes of talking to the audience. It is night and day. In no way am I disappointed in tonight's show. The band and Skiba kicked ass and sounded better than they have since pre-breakup. The music was incredible tonight and so on point, but god, this is a new band. I truly don't know what the right call is. Its 2 of the three in Blink and it shouldn't be up to Tom to decide whether they use the name based off his commitment. But tonight proved Blink is those 3, and Scott in the early years. It just is. The banter is what made them them. And without it tonight, it really could have been any other band up there. Just in terms of nothing sticks out as totally unique to them anymore besides the players. Its weird. This was a weird feeling tonight. I don't feel like I saw a Blink cover band, but I don't really feel like I saw Blink 182.

WRITING.TITLE: God, Heaven is a phenomenal closing track
WRITING.TEXT: After watching the Tom doc I was listening to I Empire again and holy fuck I forgot how good the song Heaven is. Haven't listened to it probably in years. Aside from the obvious autotune, which I actually like a lot but its clear Tom could never reach those notes at the end, its just such a killer track. God I'd love an AVA tour. So many gems he could choose from at this point.

WRITING.TITLE: Could newer Blink fans be the most honest judges of California?
WRITING.TEXT: Say, people that became fans of Blink in the last year. That would mean they are getting into Blink after their peak successful years and its no longer mainstream. They have no reason to really defend this band, unlike many of us that have been hardcores for years. In theory, they got into the band recently because the music spoke to them, presumably Enema, TOYPAJ or Self Titled. They continued listening if they liked what they heard. I would think those people could give the most honest opinion of California in that case. No matter how unbiased we may think we are, I would assume every hardcore fan has at least some opinion they can't get past (mainly either they love or hate Tom) and that will change your view of the record. A newer fan, on the other hand, can take the record on its own face value merits, because they don't really have any lasting ties to the band to think otherwise. They can more easily relate to an album just touching you regardless of whether you know or like the band or not. Thoughts?

WRITING.TITLE: I'm listening to Box Car Racer right now...
WRITING.TEXT: And crying. Its just so god damn good. Thats really all. It never fails to have the exact same impact on me as it did on my first listen.

WRITING.TITLE: Was WDNTW not praised as much as it should have been?
WRITING.TEXT: While it may sound like a cliche question I do mean it seriously. I don't think there's an easy cut and dry answer, but just curious as to opinions. Was the album disregarded by the general public or was it honored exactly as much as it should have been? Obviously Tom was coming out of Blink and there was a certain degree of hesitance or excitement or both. Angels and Airwaves, without question, never became the same level as Blink, that much is clear. But listening to WDNTW 10 years later, was it overlooked by the public? I think there's a strong argument for it, as the music is nothing displeasing and at its least captures all the elements of the other crap people listen to today. There's nothing really not to like unless you're actively comparing it to Blink. In that case you can say its a great record that no one ever really took as seriously as they should have. However, I also completely see the argument that it was rated just perfectly. It connected with a certain group, they found an appreciation of it, and for the magnitude of it thats all that really matters. Hardly any artist has two bands that hit so any praise this album got was fine. Tom himself has said he considers AVA more niche and not exactly a band, so maybe the success he's had with it is absolutely on par with that. Again, just things I'm pondering. On some days I wish the album got more attention and wasn't so bogged in the controversy, Blink and otherwise, and on others I think "its not some masterpiece record that has gone unnoticed. I like it and its a good record, but it got just as much notice as it should have." I assume the consensus will be that it should have been taken more seriously, but even I can say objectively "its good, but I'd only argue it should have been taken more seriously if it even hit me as hard as one of the classic Blink records did on first listen."

WRITING.TITLE: Gwyneth Paltrow was the worst in awhile

I was dreading Cardi B and actually thought it came off as her best interview. Thats not saying much, but I thought I'd have to skip and pleasantly heard the whole thing. The Paltrow one was a new low to me. Howard AGGRESSIVELY trying to kiss her ass and literally having NOTHING to talk about with her. And she was equally bad. Maybe she's not a total bitch but she certainly comes off as one (her mother Blythe Danner is incredible though). She gave horrible answers or at most times didn't even know what to say, although in fairness Howard was also barely asking her questions and more commenting on things and then asking for replies which she and no one would have. I don't know, this was easily his worst interview in awhile IMO. The two had zero to say to each other and everything out of Howard's mouth was basically the antithesis of everything's he's said over the years to the nth degree. "Why get married? Oh, I LOVE marriage!" I know this is probably old news to most here but holy crap was that one bad and I'm pretty easy on him with the interviews.

WRITING.TITLE: Just saw the band The Struts and made me miss this band a lot
WRITING.TEXT: So I saw Foo Fighters the other night at MSG and the opening band was this band The Struts. I had heard of them but never seen them or heard their music. Long story short, they were pretty good and I was rather impressed by the frontman. Basically a blatant Freddie Mercury rip off but he pulled it off well, but the band and the singer kept reminding me of something... Heard the album the next day and it clicked (way moreso studiowise than live): "oh, they're Foxy." Then the last two days have basically been spent reminiscing about the wonders of Foxy Shazam and how much I miss them. I don't listen to that much new music these days and these guys just clicked with me. A friend showed me Church Of Rock N Roll and I quickly heard the whole album. Fell in love with that album and the self titled, and relished my friend's stories about how the singer would hang from the rafters and eat cigarettes live. He gave me Introducing which at first I thought was way too screamo punky for me but I've grown to love and really think is an excellent album. Finally saw them live on that Church tour and they were just killer. It was outstanding. A few years went by, Gonzo finally came out and it was the first "new" album since I had become a fan. I was very underwhelmed. I thought the title track was great, and that Story Told was a masterpiece but everything in between was kinda bland. I was so upset too because they were on this great rise. Unstoppable was in a commercial, they were moving away from how they started but I thought getting buzz and a following and doing it all right. Then Gonzo came out, for free, basically as a live in the studio thing, and regardless of whether it was good or not I said then "well they just squandered everything they had been building these last few years." Maybe it wasn't a mistake, but I knew that album good or bad relegated them to being less of a "thing" than I thought they were becoming. I didn't love that record so I skipped the tour but they were coming back a year later. I realized I had to go and bought tickets finally the week of the show after wrestling back and forth. Literally 3 hours later, they broke up. I was devastated. Listening back to them over the last couple days, and after having seen that band, I just miss them so much. That band was an unstoppable force, Eric is a freak to behold and such a talented frontman which is so hard to find these days. And on top of all of that the songs were fantastic. I know they'll come back one day cause they're just too young not to, but I really thought they were going places. I've never heard the Flamingo album after all these years as I don't think its my style. Maybe I should seek it out. Anyway, just wanted to ramble. Hadn't been in a Foxy mode in awhile and get so overjoyed by their music and sad that it'll never blow up the way I thought it was going to. Short ride but made a very lasting impression on me.

WRITING.TITLE: Anyone know why Buck Henry never returned to SNL?
WRITING.TEXT: He hosted like 10 times during the original run of the show. One of, if not, the most frequent hosts in that era. Since then, I have NEVER seen him return. I don't see him at reunions, he's never hosted again, he's never even shown up when they do Five Timer's sketches. Anyone have any idea why? I know he doesn't do a ton of work but he still does stuff, like when he was on 30 Rock. I'm shocked he'd never want to return even for a cameo or something, unless he literally just left that whole life behind. I've always wondered.

WRITING.TITLE: Is this the worst cast in decades?
WRITING.TEXT: I should start off by saying I don't not like any of them. But looking at the list and binging on old clips I realize all these people have been here for quite awhile and as a cast they've been fairly unremarkable. The only true star is Kate and this has to be her last season. All the featured players are rather forgettable. All the star men (Mikey, Alex, Beck) aren't anything special at all (Beck is only the best man on the cast by default, its not impressive) and the women are all fine but have been unable to break out the way Kate has. Aidy and Cecily have been on for what, 5 years or so and don't appear to be going anywhere once the show ends. At least not in the same way Maya Rudolph or Amy Poehler did. Even the way Rachel Dratch and Ana Gasteyer did. And Leslie Jones, I'm sorry, is just a terrible sketch performer and I don't get the appeal. I'm sure none of this is terrible new, but in general this cast has been here for awhile and have done very little of note. I think its the most unremarkable cast in recent memory. The last groups went on to enormous fame, when I thought many of them might not: -Hader, Wiig, Sukedis, Samberg, Armisen, Forte, Meyers all are doing huge stuff -Cast of Fey, Poehler, Rudolph, Fallon, Parnell, Tracy doing great -Will Ferrell is the biggest of his cast but Oteri, Kattan, Hammond, Molly Shannon were all great on the show and made a lasting impression this cast hasn't. -Sandler, Spade, Farley, Norm, Rock era -Myers, Carvey, Jan Hooks, Nealon, Lovitz era. Besides that small blip in the mid 90s, this is the most unimpressive cast since the show basically rebooted in the late 80s. And unlike the blip in the 90s, this dip has been several years long. I'm not saying the show isn't good and I'm not saying these cast members aren't talented, but no one has had breakout star quality and seem to have a future career past this show. Even guys I thought like Forte or Armisen might go nowhere have done huge things. Clearly they just had more drive. I feel like this cast has been resting on a lot of sketches but as a group are fairly unremarkable. People only stand out because frankly, its just a bad cast. And props to Lorne, the last cast is hard to follow and he hadn't had to do a major overhaul in awhile. But I feel the one for the last 5 years is the weakest in 30 years.

Really is amazing how much Beth and Allison are night and day
WRITING.TEXT: I guess its really not, its actually expected and how Howard wanted it. And I promise this isn't meant to be a trash Beth post, but watching their therapy session after listening to his calls with Allison and seeing how he finally found that person that won't challenge him yet also have him wrapped around her finger. Allison was a partner, Beth was... I don't think she was a gold digger but she was just so submissive. She found a perfect situation and grabbed on. Howard screams at Allison for spending his money yet doesn't care at all about Beth buying way more expensive stuff. Her voice is essentially the exact opposite of Allison's. She's obviously conventionally very attractive so you can show that off. And listening to the therapy session, she doesn't object to anything. Its just both of them constantly trying to make the other happy, so that he can keep her and she reaps his benefits. I know its not a new observation or anything but it is so striking when you listen back to back: Howard got exactly the girl he always wanted and Beth plays it note perfect.

WRITING.TITLE: So is Sour Shoes just Brian Wilson/Syd Barrett level crazy at this point?
So who wants to explain to an idiot like me the whole Billy West scenario?
WRITING.TEXT: So I'm trying to piece this together, and I'm sure its been asked a million times, but just trying to figure out exactly went down. I'm reading conflicting (actually not conflicting) things that Billy hates the show and doesn't answer questions regarding Howard. He basically left and never looked back. Some say, himself included, that it was because of money. Others say it was other things. So then I'm surprised listening to the Howard History (that JimFixx brilliantly uploaded) Why Billy Left and Billy is participating in it. I would think he'd want nothing to do with the show. Then it says on wiki that they also had a retrospective about Billy's work on the show at some point, and the first time Billy was involved since leaving. So I wonder why that happened and why they'd do that? Are they trying to erase him or do they recognize his importance? Does Howard only not shit talk him like he does John because Billy actually became super successful? And why is there still a feud that Billy has never been back and Howard never mentions him? And then finally, where does this whole John K and Billy thing come into play. I'm listening to the interview where Howard "ambushes" Billy with John K after they had a huge falling out. Some say that was Billy's last straw that Howard was such a dick to bring him in. Why DID Howard do that and how truly awkward was that between those two? Was that literally a betrayal to Billy or just awkward?

WRITING.TITLE: In case we didn't have enough Artie videos...
Watching Ellen's special made me really want Eddie Murphy to come back
WRITING.TEXT: Not a groundbreaking thought, and one he's threatened for many years, but seeing her finally come back made me really wish he would. Listen, I'm not saying I liked her special, I really didn't. There were a few good lines but overall it didn't have the spark most great comedy has. BUT, and I think its important, she is still a comic and there is something in her and in her delivery and how she interacted (especially during the bonus audience questions) that is so inherently funny and quick and witty that I'm glad she's at least not wasting it. Sucks that its not that good IMO but I'd rather her try and fail than not at all. And I applaud her going back. Thats difficult and takes time and commitment and she did that so I give her props there. Just really made me long for Eddie. He's that one guy that really disappeared from comedy that was SOOOOO good at stand up. Delirious to this day is still one of the funniest things ever. I'm sure it wouldn't be incredible. How could it with his expectations and the world being as PC as it is? He's up against a lot. But I'd love see him up there trying. I don't know if the "I'm a rich person, here's what I've been up to" route that Ellen and other comics have would turn out better than their mediocre efforts but I'd love to see him try. Cause its not like he's not a funny guy anymore, and its a shame to see that bottled away. I think in the end it would just be too much effort, but overall it was what I was thinking about a lot during his special that I applaud that she came back and wish Eddie had the power to do the same and stopped empty threatening it. And that maybe her doing it will push him. That would be so huge to see him have a Netflix thing.

WRITING.TITLE: Watching Hilarious and very happy
WRITING.TEXT: Just remembering simpler times. I feel its been a long way of wrestling back and forth with my thoughts on current CK. Its nice to just unwind and watch some of his old stuff and just be entertained. Despite that I'm upset with the kind of person we found out he was, I don't forget the genius he is and just how awesome he truly was, and probably will be in the future. He has such a unique take and delivery on all his stuff and it really was so cool to see him go through the ranks to get to the point he finally did. He definitely deserved it. It felt like the little guy finally winning, even if he hadn't really been a little guy in the comedy scene for awhile. It was just nice to see the mainstream recognize it. Anyway its starting to sound like a eulogy. I'm happy he's still here and I don't want to hate the guy. I think that gets forgotten in a lot of this back and forth.

I know we talk all the time about Artie having the golden life there and just needing to be able to control himself in order to enjoy it, but seriously, Benjy had it MADE and pissed most of what could have been an interesting relationship with Howard down the drain. Is it really all because he's perpetually late? Is it just on the air fodder for Howard and never really genuine? Seems Benjy was given every opportunity in the world to become one of the most successful "man behind the curtain" types and he squandered them just by being incompetent. WRITING.TITLE: At what point did you grow to accept the 3 day a week schedule?
WRITING.TEXT: Just typing it out today and realizing how completely normal it seems that he has a 3 day work week (sometimes) and how fucking insane that was when it was first announced. Going from 5, to 4, to finally 3. At what point did you stop thinking about how insane that was? Does it still shock you? Nowadays I think nothing of it, but for years I was like "seriously, WTF." Crazy the way you just grow to accept things.

WRITING.TITLE: Billy Madison came out in Feb of 95, Tommy Boy in March of 95, Sandler and Farley fired in May of 95
WRITING.TEXT: I don't know, just realized to me that Sandler, Spade and Farley had huge theatrical films come out while they were still on the show. I know it occasionally happens to cast members, like Wayne's World, but god damn, thats a nuts time that three of their bigger people all were shooting movies during the summer hiatus. WRITING.TITLE: Last night's episode sucked
WRITING.TEXT: Sorry if this sounds harsh and I genuinely hope it doesn't get a million downvotes even though I wouldn't be surprised, but last night was dogshit. And Emma was totally game, but there was no material for her. Its a combo of a lot, the writing is really really terrible right now, and the performers just aren't really doing anything great. A lot of the characters have worn out their welcome or are just all the same (Heidi, who I like and really have high hopes for, but seriously every character is the same one note), and these performers just can't elevate decent sketches. Last night was such a far cry from Sandler last week and it showed for a multitude of reasons. Sandler heightened bad sketches, and the old guys he brought back were a noticeable improvement over today's quality. I genuinely think they need to let a good amount of these older cast members go and try to beef up or replace the new ones. And god damn, do something about the writing. I'm sorry, this feels super harsh but I'm a huge SNL fan. In my lifetime, this is easily the blandest its been. Genuinely don't think its been this disappointing week to week since like 96 or so. Genuinely not trying to pick fights, would gladly have a discussion about this, but seriously I think they need to do something this hiatus.

I know thats not really a surprise since we all know what he's like, but good lord its amazing its 20 years on and he hasn't changed a bit. "Sorry (insert name here), you fuck with me, I'll fuck with you back." Good lord man, you're incredibly petty. But thanks for the audio and that prank phone call to Trump. Occasionally, dude knocks it out of the park.

WRITING.TITLE: Kristen Wiig's farewell: best goodbye on SNL?
WRITING.TEXT: Springing off the Kate McKinnon thread, I had to look up Kristen's goodbye and I know that maybe Phil Hartman's goodbye is seen as the absolute best (and not taking anything away from that), and possibly for historical purposes the original cast at the end of season 5, is there ANYTHING more perfect than Kristen's goodbye. Mick fucking Jagger there to play you off with She's A Rainbow and Ruby Tuesday, each member of the cast getting to dance with her which was the sweetest thing ever (Sudekis in tears always gets me), Lorne coming up to say goodbye as well. I guess there's no place to ever really showcase this in a retrospective, but to me this is one of the top moments of the show, and absolutely the best goodbye they ever did. And Kristen so deserved it too.

WRITING.TITLE: Howard says one thing to piss everyone off - one of the best moments of the show?
WRITING.TEXT: When he tells Fred he'd be nothing without Howard, Robin can't handle criticism, Dana doesn't love Artie and Gary that he cheats on his wife. Thats gotta be one of the greatest moments in the show. Can't find the whole thing, just the Gary part, although its amazing that Gary challenged him, had a list and it STILL wasn't on there. Just as Howard predicted. Shit on Stern all you want, but he owned everyone there. Great radio.

WRITING.TITLE: The Lonely Island in NYC was fantastic!
WRITING.TEXT: Excellent show. I knew it would be fun, and it was EXACTLY what I expected, which was totally fine and a really big thrill. People have never really given Lonely Island enough credit. Their albums are great, and while the shorts are legendary, its so commonplace that people do sometimes forget how truly revolutionary that stuff was. Was cool to experience it with other fans. Highlights were definitely the Bash Brothers, We're On Stage (with Seth Meyers introducing them), I'm So Humble, Finest Girl, Lazy Sunday with Chris! Reba with Kenan! So much amazing stuff. Did I have criticisms? Sure. For nearly $100 tickets, an 80 minute show seemed A LITTLE short. Also, as a major fan, it sucked that it was mostly digital short and hit based. Its what I assumed, but I love their deep cuts. Stuff like Japan, Rocky, Perfect Saturday, so many others would be amazing to hear and are vastly underrated. I also think it would have made the show less solely based on watching music videos, which admittedly it became a lot of the time. Also, while it makes sense, it was super focused on Andy like way more than I thought. So many songs are just totally him, and I know he's front and center but I think stuff like Ras Trent and other stuff where he's the only one could be cut at the expense of group pieces. WRITING.TITLE: Summit Meeting makes Howard's kiss assing even more hilarious
WRITING.TEXT: Just thought about it while watching the address he gave. I'm a huge Bruce Springsteen fan, so as a fan its been hysterical to hear him kissing his ass SO much in the last few years, practically begging to have him on. And Bruce just, rightly or wrongly, doesn't budge. Even funnier when you factor in this video. Its like yeah, you understood that he wanted it already, but with this video you see 6 years ago he was already like "we have to inundate them. We need to be on them like white on rice." To me, it means that Howard's so pathetic that THAT plan didn't even work for some so he had to resort of openly campaigning for them on the air, something he'd make fun of any other guy for and something 15 years ago he claimed he'd never do. "If they don't want to be in here, we won't seek them out." It used to be they should be honored to come on the Howard Stern Show. Now they'll move heaven and earth to get it done. In addition it makes stuff like the Madonna move to the afternoon even more embarrassing which I didn't think was possible. He honestly might as well just have a podcast and go to their homes at this point. Just hilarious.

WRITING.TITLE: Gotta give Howard credit: he was 100% right about Sirius and responsible for its success.
WRITING.TEXT: With all the negative talk about Stern here recently (always, but with the leak even moreso), which I love, I was just listening to some old stuff and hearing before his move to Sirius. He doesn't wish anyone ill on terrestrial, he just hopes eventually everyone will come to Sirius. And it just is so interesting to think now that that IS the case how much Howard is responsible for that. Piece of shit guy, sure, but he took a risk going there and ended up being a pioneer because of it. They really do owe him a huge debt. I don't know, I just thought its funny listening to how it all went exactly as he thought. And he can sound confident then but he didn't know. Its just a fascinating listen.

WRITING.TITLE: Why does anyone really take the time to take down this guy?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm asking totally legitimately and honestly. I'll start off by saying I'm not a fan of this guy, or more appropriately I have no idea who he is and don't care. I just learned about him 30 minutes ago. What I don't understand is our current culture, where a few people on Twitter seem to go on a fact finding mission to take people down. Like WHY do you care that much?! Do people not have better things to do during the day? I couldn't care less if this guy joins the cast or now doesn't, but I just don't get people online who just sit there looking for shit on others. It seems so weird to me. I also truly don't get how people really do get so offended by stuff certain people say online. I understand thinking he's an asshole, or ignoring him, but why does everyone have to make a public opinion about anything. Like, who cares? Someone isn't for you, move on. I don't see why everyone has to take everyone down these days. No one is perfect. Didn't people have to do this for Melissa or something else when they joined? They like scoured their twitter and old tweets. Like, why?!!! Who even thinks to do that, why do you care, and what does it matter? If they're as bad as you think, we'll know immediately. Sorry, I just don't understand it.

WRITING.TITLE: Louis should go on tour with this guy fired from SNL
WRITING.TEXT: The Bad Boys Of Comedy tour. Cancel Culture strikes again.

WRITING.TITLE: FYI with the whole cancel culture thing...
WRITING.TEXT: Its not that he was funny. From everything I've seen, he really wasn't. Thats not what guys like Norm and Rob Schneider and a lot of other comedians are getting on about. Its about the fact that the show is super hard to get. That is what they sympathize with. And to have it snatched away, whether rightly or wrongly, but any rando on the internet feels wrong. Like, I get that SNL should have done better background checks, but if they didn't thats on them. The guy got the show fairly. Whether he would have succeeded or not, who knows? But there really is a movement that seems slightly dangerous and limiting that you can get everything taken away for saying something dumb. Can we not just have fun anymore? I get it, what he said was racist and bad and not fun, but we all make mistakes. I'm not siding with the guy, I have truly no involvement with the guy and couldn't really care less if he's on the show or not. But its the idea that everything you say is now under a microscope and thats yknow, not exactly what comedy is supposed to be. You'd think people at SNL and fans of the show would know that. If you don't let Eddie Murphy do his homo stuff in Delirious, would he be where he is now? (again, funny is just funny). I obviously expect the typical "what he did was different", "another rebel just trying to fight for the other side", "You don't understand racism" responses, and I haven't liked Shane's apologies, but I also have to say, I don't disagree with him on the "if you were really offended part". There are a lot of people that just like to take people down, and either say something because they think its what you're supposed to say these days, or people that pretend to be outraged. Thats not false at all. But whatever, guy's gone. We'll move on. But it was SNL's fault for not catching it sooner. If you gave him the show, you shouldn't yank it away.

WRITING.TITLE: Loved the show, but I'm sorry, what's going on with Tom's mini strokes every 30 seconds?

WRITING.TEXT: I'm not anti-New Blink. I'm a little disappointed in the direction Mark has gone. I feel he's just really sold out and feels the brand needs to be a certain way to still have mass appeal, instead of leading it with integrity and the spirit the band used to have. Having said that, I totally get WHY he's doing it and I don't begrudge him. We all gotta make a living and at this stage in life, this makes the most sense if you're gonna be Blink and still want to be a "new". As for this album though, I'm not sure what they were thinking. I mean, actually I think I do: we need to play stuff that sounds reminiscent of our old stuff while also inexplicably singing songs about tweens when we're 45. First song? Its literally just Feeling This lite. Second song intro? Its just Stay Together For The Kids. Blame It On My Youth is just Man Overboard. The reminiscent stuff just comes off sounding lazy, like they don't have anything left to offer. Please let me know what I'm missing here, I'm sorry I'm just not seeing it. I didn't love California, but by comparison it seems like a masterpiece to me. At least I got what they were going for with that, and I thought it sounded Lite but that it still sounded like Blink. This I just don't even think sounds like them. And not that you can't change over time or that I need it to sound similar, but I just don't get the direction at all. I'm shocked by the reviews I'm reading comparing to Self Titled.

WRITING.TITLE: Getting a new phone: Pixel 1, Pixel 3 or Pixel 3a?
WRITING.TEXT: Hi guys, (USA) Got a new phone a couple months ago and wanted a Pixel. To my surprise, the guy was pushing the Pixel 1 instead of the Pixel 3 or Pixel 3a which had just come out when I went there. Obviously, I was surprised cause you don't usually go back buying old phones, but he was convincing. Pixel 1 was built to last longer, the new models don't have headphone jacks and are slimmer but because of the slimness some of the resistance the first one had has gone away. He said its still his best seller and he doesn't like the new ones. Bought it, went home and of course everyone laughed at me for buying an old phone. Figured he was just pushing out stock. I checked online and it looks like the 3 and 3a get good reviews so its really just this guy. Long story short, phone now won't vibrate so I need a replacement anyway. The guy said he could just give me a 3 if thats what I wanted and I'm having second thoughts. What should I do? Stick with the 1? Is he right that its way better? Is he just trying to fleece me? I'm happy to have the choice but honestly just want whatever is a good phone (it doesn't have to be the newest model) and it looks like everywhere online the new phones get good reviews so its hard to tell.

And then hearing stuff with Aniston where he's saying "at a certain point its definitely HER fault that she can't keep a man" and that "if given the chance, she seems like the kinda girl that would balloon up to 200 pounds." And this is from 10 years ago or less. Its not like this is early 90s and he's no one. Its just truly crazy to hear that stuff then see him on vacation with Aniston and kissing Ellen on her show. This thing I'm listening to with Ellen he's talking about how she ran a dog shelter out of business. He paints her horribly. Now she's like "I was showing George Bush your paintings." Hollywood is fuckin insane.

WRITING.TITLE: The obvious question: is all this Brent stuff just rehearsed and scripted?
WRITING.TEXT: Today sounded like the first glimpse of semi-classic Howard where you wanted to keep listening. My reaction to that is: that seems fishy lol. They never seem to be able to come up with anything compelling, and now all of a sudden this falls right into their lap? I've been on Shuli's side for most of this, and I hate Shuli. But its seemed like Brent talks a big game, but in the end is an ogre that can't get anyone to have sex with him. Now we have this and I guess it begs the question are they staging all of us this just to get us talking? I'm just having trouble with a lot of aspects of it. That this crew, even accidentally, is capable of creating something truly worth listening to. I'm having trouble with why Robin was SO pissed and on fire. It seemed like every person had a role that they were meant to play. Something seemed off. Maybe thats paranoia, I have no idea. I'd like to believe its real. But so much of this show is scripted now, its not unbelievable to think this might be too. The woman on the phone sounded wishy washy about the whole thing too. I don't know, it seems like the subreddit unanimously liked it, which I did as well. Does everyone think its real, or just something they've been brewing for a while now with Shuli accusing Brent and everything else. It does seem like a slow burn you could cook up in a writing meeting when it seems like there's no evidence they do any other work on this piece of shit show.

I think those are all very good points. I actually agree with most of them. I don't feel the need TO defend them, but I guess how I've always seen them is: 1. When Susan says that to Ross, I don't see it as implying being gay is a bad thing, even though everything you say is absolutely right. I think it CAN be read that way, but I think the intention is to bring that issue to a larger audience. Ross is concerned, because of how Carol changed and he's now the one who feels left out. I get the argument of Ross being homophobic, but I almost every time I think its more that he's upset about change and he's upset about being left out. Which, as a white man, I'm hardly saying I have sympathy for him, but just saying that I don't think any of the perceived homophobic stuff is blatantly malicious which is why I just don't think its actually there. I think it can be read that way, but I also think its just using humor to show its just different, but they never say bad. I guess you could say thats a technicality, but I'm just saying thats how I've seen it. Ross is acting the way most fathers would, whether good or bad, the same way Kevin Hart and Tracy Morgan have had jokes that were in a similar capacity. But that neither are anti-gay, that the joke is just truly because its different than the antiquated "normal" system. They're pointing it out, in an effort to show its not actually wrong. 2. "Where are all the men?!" I just see as a funny line. Nothing more. Its like when Joey is arranging flowers and says "oh my god, I'm a woman!" Thats honestly just real life. Its not demeaning people that like that stuff. Its just, sometimes when you're a guy you act girly. Its not bad but I also get why people would make fun of it at times. If anything, just own it. 3. I do remember the A man Duh joke which I just remember as dumb, but not mean. Its more just bad sitcom writing than anything else. Its embarrassing for THAT, not cause its anti gay. The thing about the "MAN in the black dress" I totally think you're right and I think its the epitome of how people are just TOO sensitive now. I get it, I don't want anyone to feel left out, but its just a funny line and also has a hint of truth to it. I think someone like Caitlyn Jenner would understand if you said that line to her cause, yknow, we're all not blind. I've never quite understood why there's the argument that stuff is upsetting to others, yet we can never have the argument that maybe people are legitimately too sensitive about some things in this day and age. Sometimes funny is just funny. I assume the comeback to that would be "then if you're so funny, do it in a different way thats not offensive" which I'm sure could be done, but also if this works I don't see a problem. Again, I'm not trying to say there's no way I'm wrong. This is just how I've seen them, while also understanding that other side. I don't want to say the show is perfect but I still can't really find ANYTHING that I find indefensible, and usually the stuff pointed out is tame. Maybe I really just don't see it and am belittling this stuff but I'm really trying not to be. I genuinely feel the fact that they had David Crane at the helm is key to the argument too that its all just meant in good fun. If he weren't there, I feel I'd have less of a leg.
Beautiful article, and he's a cool guy. "You mean, they cut the frontier gynecology sketch?!" (takes off his latex gloves). He was totally underrated.

I think there's also two very big things that would come from that: its seen that if you give someone more time, they can do something like Tim Robinson's show. Thats not what improv and sketch really is. Either it works or it doesn't. But back then they weren't thinking "will this be great 40 years from now?" Its does it work now and thats what SNL is. I like them a lot, but as it is right now I feel they've got a lot to do to reach the heights of previous head writers who also happened to be cast members. The main ones before them were Seth Meyers and Tina Fey. Again, Che and Jost are good, but they aren't those guys. Someone like Meyers lived for the show. He cared about it so much, he'd go to the wall fighting or rewriting sketches for him but mostly others. He cared about putting on a quality show every week, caring about every facet of the program and not just weekend update. Not accusing the current two of NOT doing that, but just noting. Similarly with Tina Fey, there was a passion that you could feel on the program. You could feel that this sketch was benefitted from a punch up from Fey or Meyers. That they would forgo sleep to make YOUR sketch, and by extension the entire show, better. They were Lorne's right hand people that he trusted like not many throughout the show's history. They are properly honored usually but I'd argue deserve more credit than they'll ever receive for helping keep this show on the air and relevant. Their passion for the show was truly unparalleled and kind of superhuman, so while I wouldn't expect it from Jost or Che or any future head writers/cast members, I also don't think they have it at all. Che in particular seems like, and I mean it nicely, that this is a cushy job and he does well but not above and beyond. Jost maybe a little more but again, very much is doing his work well as opposing to carrying the entire show on his back. If anyone were to take over for Lorne, I'd say it would be Seth.

BUT I also thought what would have been so quintessential Louis was him owning up to it when the rumors were around and just being like "unfortunately its true, it really sucks, and I'm sorry to those who felt offended by it and I don't do it anymore." I don't know if it was Artie or just Howard was better back then (probably a little of both), but seriously, the show was just so much fucking better than. It was just so naturally entertaining. Nowadays its truly a pale imitation cause its trying to be the same thing but it just reeks so hard of being forced. I was just listening to a Ben Stiller interview on youtube from when Artie was there and it starts off with Jimmy Kimmel being in with the group that day. He's being the same as he was then, actually he was being more of a kiss ass saying he got the speech he gave at Howard's wedding framed for him which is just massively cringe, yet it was still so much more entertaining than today's drek. Artie helped, but its just night and day a different show.

But it isn't just Artie. Artie was invaluable, don't get me wrong, as was that third chair, but its not just that. The show isn't funny because Howard has utterly stopped trying, the cast doesn't have a funny person in there, and the show had to skew towards political correctness. All of those things, make it a pale imitation of what it was. Cause they haven't changed the format, they've just taken the urgency, excitement, funny people and inappropriate conversations out of the equation. And you're left with a hollow version of what was once a great show. But its not JUST the third mic thing.

He did do something wrong, its just different than what most people actually think he did. What he did was lie to his fans and by not admitting to his transgressions, silenced women who were trying to speak up about something that happened to them. What he DIDN'T do was rape people. He DIDN'T rape people. Thats important. What he did do was lie and use his power (in the early days as a head writer on shows, and in the later days as a relatively respected comic on the underground circuit) to keep himself protected from creepy weird things he did. It is up to you whether you think that second part constitutes a "wrong" act. Personally I think it does. Woody Allen dating and marrying his adopted daughter is another thing I think is wrong even though its not illegal. Having said that, I appreciate that he was upfront about it and never tried to hide it. I didn't like that Louis hid it for so long and made other people seem like liars by not answering to it. To me, that is wrong. everyone has a different scale.

Probably gonna get downvoted but it isn't meant as harsh as it sounds. This sketch is a perfect example of why I've always thought this cast was competent but never able to go for that second level. This is a fine idea, and obviously these two are capable of performing it, but thats about it. It never elevates anywhere. I feel like any of the recurring sketches in the past, there's an embodiment that elevates the sketch beyond just what's on the written page. I don't see that here. Its just two performers compentantly performing what's on the page, but failing to really make it go beyond that. Something like Wayne's World, the Sweeny Sisters, it was the performance that made the sketch. Not every one was great, but they were fully committed to the bit and the character, whereas I always felt these ended up rather bland. It doesn't even really have the same feel as say the Porn Stars sketch, which again is sold by their commitment. I think this sketch is pretty symbolic of what this cast (minus Kate) is: good, but not great and really able to fully sell a sketch unless the writing is just impeccable (which has also usually not been the case in the most recent years). If you have better performers, that can be masked, but if both are just fine I feel it shows.

The whole story rubs me the wrong way. I like Pete a lot and I really used to like Louis CK a lot. I still do, hopefully that doesn't taint this whole post. I think what he did was terrible, the act but moreso the lying and silencing people which he was able to do because he was a huge name. I didn't like the way it was handled and would have loved if he came clean, so while I still like his old material, that aspect really bothered me about him. But ok, past all that, what I didn't like about this story is it just seems like convenient timing. It seems easy to knock him down. I get it that maybe Pete didn't have an outlet till now. But its a very personal story that he's trying to use public and other people's pain to convey. It seems unLouie to do this, even though I believe the story, but its put in a worse light because he's kind of disgraced now. I think the joke relies on Louie being down and out, which to me is a sign that it doesn't really work, if that makes sense. Again, I like Pete a lot, but just seems like an easy way to get praise against a guy who's already taken down on you. Its a cool story, but he's wrong about the fallout now. Publicly yes, but comedian wise almost everyone stood by him. Again, much to my annoyance that none of the comedians will say he did anything wrong and that the media blows it up as if he did something worse than he actually did. The story just sounds bitchy to me rather than a great comic routine.

Its not an opinion. I've seen him live and I'm watching the special now. I saw him live TWICE! Its the material I saw. And it was undercooked then. Still seems to be. I'm not trying to rag on him. I'm trying to have a discussion with people that actually like him, same way I do. I really like Pete. I wish he was better. I don't know why I can't post that. The other threads are overwhelmingly negative, and here I think people could have an honest discussion. But if you want me to leave, fine.

Trust me, couldn't care less about the downvoting. Not gonna be slitting my wrists because someone on the internet didn't like me. Listen, its not opinion, it really is a fact, but whatever. If you appreciate the subpar comedy, thats your right. I think its sad that he's clearly capable of more and just doesn't get better. He'll stay at this mediocre level if people just accept this as being good. I think pushing him to do better when he's got the talent to isn't a bad thing to say, and its also not an opinion, its a fact. In a day, he's put me on a roller coaster ride. That interview with Charlamagne thats making all the news was REALLY good. He was really coherent, level headed, right about a lot of things. Then I watch his special and I'm like "oh, but you're still... you're still just kind of coasting though." Listen, if he didn't do his great Weekend Update pieces it'd be a different story. But he's really good on those so there's no reason he can't translate that to stand up. If he sucked there too, I'd just say he isn't that great at comedy. But he is and thats what's frustrating. Its hard for me to root for him and champion him in that interview when then the product is subpar. The interview was great and if he had a great special to follow it, this would be a great moment. Being what it is, I think its yet again another missed opportunity. His last special was better than this one.

Compared to his own comedy in other venues as well as just the history of comedy specials in general, it is not an opinion. But I'm glad others are enjoying it. He's definitely capable of more though. I'm surprised this didn't include the bit about his friend dying and him thinking it was a bit.

Totally agree. You said it better than I could ever hoped to have. Again, most of MY criticism of the cast comes from that. Not from them not being talented, not from them not being capable. Sure, I do think they are... lazy seems like the wrong word, but just limited in what they can do. In that they can pretty do anything you write for them, but they don't have that extra level that pushes them to truly take the stuff off the page the way previous cast members have. Say what you want about guys like Samberg, Forte, Armisen, Cheri Oteri, Chris Kattan, etc, but they were able to do what was asked AND above. Maybe they all didn't go on to huge stardom, but they were great on the show. Cheri Oteri could do what you ask of her but was then also writing her own fully formed characters in the tradition of the show. I don't see this cast doing that. The terrible sketch with Kate and Aidy as sisters in like an old timey movie. I get it, but the reason I don't think it really jumps off is because I don't think its written by them. Its a sketch someone is writing hoping to be recurring, and they can do it well, but there's a personal touch to it thats missing. Thats my gripe with them. The political stuff is just in addition to that, and also to me a sign that they can't CREATE a character. Will Ferrell CREATED that George Bush. Darrell Hammond CREATED that Bill Clinton. Someone like Cecily can play Jeanine Pirro very well, and I think its really funny, but she's just doing Jeanine. She's not creating a character, if that makes sense. She's just capable of doing a really good impression of her. Maybe I'm selling them short, but I think its telling that the only one that CAN do it, and gets called to, is Kate. I don't even like Kate that much, but I can't deny she's a star with extreme talent that does what all great SNL performers have done in the past (whether they went on to superstardom or not after SNL) which is take every sketch off the page. I think what Lorne has, and had for like 6 years at this point, is a cast thats very capable, but isn't able to go that extra mile. They do what's asked of them, and they do it well, but they aren't truly creating for the show in their own voice, which is why Lorne has either fallen back on celebrities doing the impressions or just not figured out how to use them. And Lorne has a good track record, I really don't think its a coincidence that I've thought this for years about this cast (again, not shitting on them) and now none of them play major candidates. They needed to HOPE Warren went all the way, and now what, they're just gonna have Larry David and a revolving Biden the rest of the season? And again, still Baldwin as Trump. As you say, this is coming from a place from an SNL wannabe history buff lol. You just can't NOT notice this, while also liking this cast.

WRITING.TITLE: Do you think he'll truly ever get over this "scandal"?
WRITING.TEXT: For the record, I think he will and always have, but I'm just curious. So he's playing theaters now, obviously outside major cities but at this point clearly playing places that show enough people still want to see him. I was gonna argue Coronavirus will actually help him, because it provides a self imposed retreat from society a bit more, and will also reset people's minds a bit more about the entire world. But will he ever really be away from this thing to the general public? His fans will forgive him, and have, but would he be accepted back on say, talk shows again? Will he just plain never do mainstream media again? For example, I don't see him ever playing MSG again, but like, how much bigger than his current level do you think he can get to again? Will he ever be talked about in mainstream society without this being brought up? Just wondering how much it'll be synonymous with his career. In a way, the way you don't think of OJ Simpson without thinking of the murders. Obviously Louis didn't kill anyone, but just wondering since its still in the public consciousness how long you think it stays there? In 5 years, is it still something brought up when referencing him? Letterman's stuff never is.

Really sucks, cause the tour was going so good. I feel incredibly lucky to have seen him in NJ before this all really got insane. Crazy to think how literally every single thing is cancelled, NJ is on complete lockdown, and basically has been for a week already, when 2 and a half weeks ago I was seeing Louis with no care in the world make his comeback. I remember that feeling, so I really feel for the people who are getting screwed by this.

Its amazing that its possible thats not even his best special. I think its absolutely brilliant, but I'd maybe give the slight edge to Hilarious or Shameless. But that Beacon one is just truly something to behold. I remember when it came out and it felt that way before even seeing it. And then seeing it and watching it deliver. Its insane. Again, possibly his best special, but even if its not, its the only one I watch where I'm like he can do whatever he wants on stage and it'll be amazing. He was at that "once in a lifetime" moment for a comedians, and it was a such a vindicating time for Louis fans. He had been around for SO long and was finally getting his due and it was so sweet. Every move he made on stage was just so naturally as good as it could get. If anything, its why I judge Oh My God so harshly, because I just didn't think it even touched Beacon, which is kinda unfair because Louis was in such a mode at Beacon's time that was already kinda gone by Oh My God.

While I get what you're getting at, and you're not wrong in some circles these days cause there are some people who just want to get outraged about everything (I don't however believe its the majority that actively post the way you're saying it), largely I feel like people were angrier about a different thing when this all started. It definitely became overblown, but the real anger from people that weren't just latching on was that he silenced women with his power and put them in uncomfortable positions. He wasn't really like any other media figure getting accused of things, but it didn't make his thing right. Sure, it was more "weird" than "wrong" but these women deserved to have their time to speak. And it affected Louis for a bit, and now after a year he was back out doing comedy and two years later he's back out to selling a special. I think there's less anger in him releasing a special mainly because he's now just doing things on his own again, or always was. You can't get mad at a guy who's doing things from his own website, because at that point he's not forcing it on anyone, and maybe I'm giving people too much credit but I actually think they're rational enough to see that. Its not the same as when he came back after less than a year and people thought that was too soon which, regardless of whether it was or not, it was something people had to get through unless he wanted to disappear for like 5 years. My point is, I think at this point people have either forgiven him or haven't. They aren't just arbitrary getting up in arms about him releasing a special the way they were about his return to comedy in general. Personally, I've forgiven him because I was upset he lied to me as a fan about these rumors the very few times he addressed them and I just think had he owned up to it awhile ago when it was also out there this NEVER would have stained his career. And we'd all be better for it. I've now forgiven him because the consequence of it is, unfortunately, it'll probably dog him the rest of his career, or at least for a really long time now. So I can't stay mad at him since its not like he's getting off scot free. This is his cross he has to bear and it'd be silly for me or others to really be that mad at him at this point. Had he come back and it seemed like nothing ever happened, yeah I'd think that was wrong for the women, but thats not what happened and he's now going to deal with it however he sees fit but I feel comfortable giving him money again.

There's just no way Community doesn't make a movie. I'm not even saying they should, but I just think "Six Seasons and A Movie" was too big a running phrase in the show and the fact that they miraculously made it to six seasons (thats really the biggest surprise IMO) that it has to happen. Its too PERFECT a thing for them to capitalize on to not, especially when there really aren't that many things for them to capitalize on. Plus, they all fuckin adore the show. I just think its too many factors for it to not happen. They would readjust their schedules to make it happen I truly believe. I unfortunately think its just going to be all of them but Donald and he'll just cameo for like 10 minutes or something, even though I really think he and Chevy should be involved so that its the full gang. But the fact that it made it six seasons AND the cast is all still really big in their own right independent of the show... at this point I'd be more shocked if it doesn't happen, and I'm shocked myself to hear me say that. Having said that, I do think they have to do it sooner rather than later. I think they have 3 years to capitalize on it, MAYBE 5, but they're already WAY older. I guess that doesn't matter but I think after 5 years the show just wouldn't be relevant in the same way, and I think after 3 years, storywise, it feels WAY too trying. You do it relatively soon and I genuinely don't think it would be questioned at all.

WRITING.TITLE: I hate how the show and Chevy handled the Pierce thing
WRITING.TEXT: I've simultaneously always been really mad at how the show minimizes Pierce's importance and how Chevy Chase fucked up what will end up being the last good thing of his career. The character of Pierce was great. He was hysterical, and a lot of that was due to Chase. It truly can't imagine anyone playing the character better, and he was always really hilarious and an integral character to the show to me. The character was so funny that even when he wasn't on screen he could make an entire scene, like his will reading. I hate how because the cast really hated Chevy that once he left they not so subtlety imply the character was never more than just a racist and not all that important to the show. You can not like Chase, but be upfront and talk about how god damn funny that character was and that, despite everything, Chase played him great. At the exact same time, I've always been furious that Chevy fucked up a good thing. Chevy had NO business being on a hit show. He hadn't done anything remotely successful since the 80s. He gets the unlikeliest chance to get back in the spotlight and in the most unsurprising Chevy move, he squanders it. He was working with an incredible group of actors, a showrunner who is revered in this day an age, and directors who have now directed some of the top grossing movies of all time. You had nothing, somehow got everything, and managed to ruin it all with your ego. If you just put it aside just a bit, you could have had the a rather undeserved but stellar end to a rather disjointed career. You were handed it on a silver platter, and worse, you were GREAT on the show. So either you were naturally amazing by not trying, or you tried a lot when you needed and STILL crapped on the show. Either way, it leaves me feeling disappointed because I love your work on the show but believe every story I hear about you from that cast.

Nope, totally agree. That is part of my whole thing against "the show". By "show", I really mean Harmon, who seemed determined to be just as much of a diva as Chevy. He fostered a bad environment for Chase, and I assume it wasn't unwarranted, but that was my whole point that if they're all saying Chase didn't handle it correctly, neither did Dan.

I've never seen the racist stuff as things they claim he said in real life. I've seen where they talk about using real lines he's said but its usually that crazy way he speaks like, not racist things. It was more homophobic than anything else.
Its kind of the summation of his career. Chevy HAS talent, but the second he gets an inch of success it goes directly to his head.

The last good thing he did was The Three Amigos, and the only thing you could give him is Christmas Vacation, which I don't like but I know some others do. So he hasn't done anything since 1986 or 1989 besides Community.

I don't disagree, but Dan Harmon is just as bi polar as Chevy. Funny thing is Chevy THINKS he has the clout to act that way when Harmon actually has the TALENT to act that way. But both of the ways they lash out are wrong and I don't think one is more to blame over the other. I'm not absolving Chevy of anything, although I genuinely think its too easy to say they only acted that way because he sucked. Dan was fucking with him a lot, maybe not even that seriously, but others went along with it and it became a mutiny against Chevy. I think Chevy is awful and I've read the stories, but I always think they went A LITTLE hard on him. Or at least that it was coming from a bad place when, most of what Chevy says, is harmless. That doesn't exclude it, but its usually not malicious.

With all due respect, I don't think much of that is correct. Hader, as mentioned, was saved by many of the writers. He's also enormously talented and creative, but he was there with a good crop and that definitely saved his ass too. Jay, I hate to say it, but I think got screwed mostly because he's black. SNL self admittedly will never be the voice of black America, and its very hard for a black cast members to break through. Kenan is a rare exception, and its not to knock him, but I think Jay had more aspirations than Kenan did. Kenan has carved a place for himself, but I think for many black cast members its hard to just fit in and you get relegated to the background unless you have a lot of crossover appeal. I think Jay probably had a lot of great ideas that just didn't gel with the very white staff on the show. I'm not calling him the next Eddie Murphy or anything, but I think he was capable of a lot and his stuff just didn't click with the staff so they relegated him to impressions. It was unfortunate cause I like to think he was hired because he's more. Melissa, I have to imagine, has a lot of characters the writers just don't think will work. And either its the writers fault or she's mediocre. I really like her when she's on the show, so I hope its the latter and that they just aren't tapping into her when they could. Its hard to tell these days. I kinda like Heidi too but every one of her characters sounds and acts the same. I don't know if thats a her thing or the writers not knowing how to use her. Unfortunately, Melissa has been on the show for what, 5 years? I really have to imagine at this point she's not on a ton because her stuff just isn't good enough. Or she's been getting dealt a really crappy hand of not being heard. But in 5 years, I have to imagine its more on you than the staff. Who knows.

WRITING.TITLE: Really hoping next year is a rebirth for this show
WRITING.TEXT: Thats not to say this season or cast was bad, but I just really feel the show is kinda stuck in a rut. I give the cast tremendous credit for trying and doing the best they can with the material they either write or is given to them, but I really feel its been a long transition period between cast members who have been there awhile and seem hard pressed to give anything truly new and a newer cast that either hasn't found its footing or is getting overshadowed by the elder members. I like to imagine all cast members that are hired are hired for a reason, which is why I really wish they'd let more of these featured players shine a bit more. I'm not sure why the lack of material from most of them, but if its a writing fault they should definitely be considered more. If its the performer's fault, then maybe start looking for replacements, but there are a lot of underutilized cast members, namely most of the women, that I'd love to see get a bigger spotlight. I'm also really dying for some of this cast to leave. Its truly nothing against them personally, but Cecily, Aidy, Kate, Pete have all been there for a really long time. Beck and Kyle as well. I really think this cast could use an overhaul. Again, nothing against them, but I just feel they've given all they can to this show, some great stuff, and its time for a new guard. You have about 16 people now, 8 of which could definitely anchor a new cast, the same 2 weekend update personalities. I really think its time to shake up those 6 that have been there since like 2012/2013.

Yeah, it wasn't a great show but not trying to immediately be negative as I know that usually gets a lot of downvotes. But yeah, calling a spade a spade, it was a major step down from the last episode, and I'd argue the worst of the 3.

WRITING.TITLE: Is there anyone that was as good as Howard was for as long as he was?
WRITING.TEXT: Yes, I hate the shows nowadays as well. Its terrible. BUT obviously I'm still here because of how good the show was for so long. He was so consistent for so long. Who else is at that level? I know a lot of bands and personalities and TV show who had a good 10 years or so, but Howard was pretty excellent consistently for like 20 years. Again, not saying he's God or anything. Guys like Steven Spielberg or someone have had incredible careers, but just wondering who else has been as consistent as Howard was for a while. Or if not, how long do you feel he was consistently great?

We had Ferrell/Oteria/Kattan, then Fey/Fallon/Poehler, then Samberg/Hader/Wiig, with key anchors like Forte, Armisen and Meyers during the in betweens. And of course Kenan throughout all of that. I feel like since Killam, Bayer, and others left, the show has just been very meh most weeks. I don't even love Kate, but I think she's the only one who's carried the load in the same way Wiig, Ferrell and others have in the past.

BUT I'm also so lazy, I don't wanna do this presentation more than once, so everyone will hear it now and we'll work out the details later. There's just so many layers of stupidity to it it never gets old. His incessant calling out of High Pitch Mike. So much wrong with it on so many levels. 1. That he only sees him for gay stuff, which is completely against what he's trying to portray that Howard is the almighty PC king and doesn't have preconceived notions about anyone or anything, when this is truly who he really is. 2. That Mike has ever been portrayed as anything other than yet another punching bag in this gang of idiots. Like, why would Mike be at all able to handle this. It'd be like asking Stuttering John to do it. Or when Howard calls out Ralph as having great ideas. Its like, you realize how retarded you sound? You obviously don't. You may as well have had the wack packers in on the meeting and given Action items to Erik. Again, every bit of this is brilliant. And we only know that, because Howard would have obliterated someone ELSE for doing this back in the day. He's done it enough that its in OUR DNA to see this stuff. The disconnect is just stunning.
