This one seemed so boring and tedious. 2. Didn't disagree with anything he said. I actually thought that "bit" was the most interesting one of the special. Its not new or something other comedians haven't talked about, and done it better, but its so incredibly relatable for many of us that would never think to do it that I still find it interesting. And yeah, I thought he was totally on point there. 3. I didn't necessarily think it was as pointed at Louis as you made it out to be. I get how he's part of it, but it seemed VERY general and applicable to all the bad people like Weinstein and such. It was really just a bit about powerful people doing these weird things, and how its hard to get true consent when you're a big deal. I guess the most applicable thing to Louis was the "even if they say yes" but honestly, it didn't read to me pointed at Louis. I have no idea what he's said about Louie since this has gone down, but it just seemed like a general bit about no one is enthusiastically agreeing to seeing someone jerk off. I thought it applied to Weinstein and Charlie Rose as directly as it did to Louis, but thats just me. Either way, I thought what he said was on point and the fact that he didn't name check Louis is why I'm not gonna hold it against him. What I'll hold against him is that set was far below par what I've seen him do in the past and that was sad.

Even for a low budget comedy its not good. Dirty Work is an excellent low budget comedy. This, and I love Artie to death, was nothing more than a vehicle for Artie to talk about. If it was great, it would have been amazing, but if it was bad it was just like "yeah, we expected that" and its the type of vanity project no one would hold against him. To call it better than a 4 out of 10 is being far too kind.

Harvey Weinstein jerked off at people, into plants, walked out in robs. Again, I imagine Louis was included in the group, but I thought it spoke to the whole MeToo movement. At no point did I think "oh, only Louis", but maybe thats just me.
I would argue this is literally the epitome of the early Sirius years. This is one the best videos of all of them, period.

WRITING.TITLE: Why wasn't Louis involved in the Dana Carvey Show documentary?
WRITING.TEXT: Its strange, he's like the only one NOT involved, yet he was the head writer there. Literally everyone else from the show was involved. I think what also made it stranger for me is it came out like a week, if I remember correct, after he went down in 2017. Obviously, they didn't reedit it in any way, but it almost seemed like it was just like "not the right time" to use him, yet it seems like he was never included which is odd to me because obviously they didn't know what was about to happen to him.

They obviously couldn't get him and he's such a big presence on the show that I'm surprised he didn't sit with them.

Well it was an open secret.

Yeah, I don't begrudge him or anything. I just assume he was busy. And I also would have liked to see Dino and Kaufman, but they are both kind of aloof guys to me. I don't know. Louis felt weird because at the end they're all kinda like "i'd do anything for Dana" cause that show really was a HUGE stepping stone for them, and not that I thought Louis not being there meant he wasn't grateful, but more that as head writer it would have been really interesting to hear him speak about it. I think its invaluable info. I just wasn't sure if anyone here knew why he wasn't involved. His absence is definitely the most conspicuous of the bunch.

WRITING.TITLE: Anyone else think its amazing how quick they just moved on from Artie?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm finishing up the fantastic Artie Lange Addiction Saga, and I'm in December of 2009. Its basically clear Artie is just not gonna be coming back, but its pretty amazing in hindsight how they just blew past the whole thing. Yes, he tried to kill himself, and that became clear he was gonna be gone, at least for awhile, but this is someone they worked with for a decade. Even if they were sick of him, it seems pretty nuts to me that just all of a sudden he wasn't there, which must have been weird for all the main people, and they basically just stopped talking about him. I guess its not totally different than Jackie or John, who rarely got mentioned once they left, but it just seems shocking to me that for all the the grief Artie caused them for him to all of a sudden not be there they never really talked about "hey, its weird Artie's not here anymore, right?" He was literally in the group of 5 with Howard, Robin, Fred and Gary and then just all of a sudden was gone and rarely mentioned. Maybe its just listening in this fashion, but its astounding how quickly they moved on. I'm not saying didn't care, but just didn't mention how strange it was not having him there anymore. I guess he'd missed enough that they were used to it?

Its just amazing that if I hung out with someone every day for a decade they'd be a part of my life that probably comes up decently regularly. Its like how Howard will just ask Robert Plant about Led Zeppelin when he hasn't been in Led Zeppelin for 40 years. It was so impactful that no matter what you're talking about it'll come up. Its just crazy that a guy was in that room for a decade then barring a few calls, he's never brought up and they didn't in the beginning of 2010 be like "this is weird."

I don't think they should have taken off work. I just think that would be nuts for someone that big to leave and no one to replace him. If that happened at my job, I do believe we'd still bring up that unfortunate guy.
I truly feel the same.
I genuinely believe him when he never thought suicide was possible. He knew it was bad and maybe encouraged some, but I don't think he saw that happening.

I guess Jackie never seem strange because the show changed and someone replaced Jackie. No one replaced Artie so the hole felt more noticeable. And he was an everyday thing whereas Scott was big but not in studio.

I'm listening to his addiction saga and 2009 takes up so much of it. Its mostly 07 and 09, and 09 gets the brunt of it. When you listen to 2009 back to back to back, its truly shocking in retrospect. He was so bad. Yet then he got in such great shape in mid 2009, he had the Joe Buck thing. Like, he was so active for someone doing so fucking badly.
Thats literally not what I said at all.
I didn't say they needed to replace him. I'm just saying they didn't so the absence seemed more noticeable than the Jackie transition.. Reading comp.
And the show wasn't even good here. This was a rare good day.
Its great to see Gary arguing with Robin and she's not even there lol.
I didn't, but fine.

I mean, Artie is a big boy. What happened to Artie would have probably happened whether he was on the show or not, and whether Howard was making a bit of it. Artie was disrespecting the show, the show addressed it the way they did because they had to say something and they tried to make it entertaining. I don't think it was malicious and I still don't really hold the show as much to blame. They really tried to help him, and they didn't want it. If he was gonna keep coming in, they were gonna keep goofing on him.
I'm not pretending. I explained exactly what I said. If you wanna make it the other way, thats fine. Its the internet and you can't convince morons to change their minds. Thats like Internet 101.
I typed exactly what I meant. Can we just bone already cause my dick is hard and I can only stay wet for so long.
Its 2020. Nothing to be confused by. We're all men and we're all women. Glad to hear you're turned on though.
Doesn't look anything like Simon Cowell.

People are retarded here. I'm not surprised.

WRITING.TEXT: Seriously, that service was so fucking good. I know we like shitting on him, but for like 5 or so years that in demand service was fucking incredible in the content it produced.

Hated the movie, just wanna say that off the top. Burr was good in it, but the movie basically glorifies Pete's behavior, and when it doesn't it doesn't give a firm stance on it. By the end of the movie, I guess its assumed Pete's change, but there's really no growth shown and nothing to prove he isn't exactly the same or learned anything. Ok, then about them being in it and saying things, I don't think any said anything so horrible at the time that Louis wouldn't understand. Pamela was in an unwinable situation with him. She's intrinsically linked to most of his career and he did questionable stuff. I can't imagine she didn't know, I can't imagine he didn't ask her, I can't believe she didn't say yes honestly. But regardless of the fact, she had to get past it and disassociate, and I don't think she ever was out of line. I don't like that I think she knew, but I thought she handled it well. As for Burr, I also don't think he said anything over the line. I think its fair to be disappointed in Louis, I certainly was. But I don't think he's taken low blows at him and Burr is a pretty straight shooter. I think he just thought the whole situation sucks and that he doesn't blame or encourage Louis' behavior but ultimately falls on the line of "if the man is still funny, he deserves another chance." I haven't seen him really convey otherwise. As for Pete, you know, if Louis did that, then I understand where Pete's coming from and he gets lucky to crap on Louie and I'd say he deserves to be able to. Maybe its a little childish, but if Louis did what Pete is saying he did, I gotta side with Pete and say he's allowed to air it out and hit him back a little. If it didn't happen that way, then Pete's out of line and thats really unfair to shit on Louis when he was already at his lowest in the mainstream.

Here's what I think: It was not finely crafted material, and what we got last night was fine but not fantastic. I wasn't offended, but what was missing was that Louis CK style construction that Bill is definitely capable of and probably hasn't had due to no audience. But Louis' child molester bit is a perfect example of how you CAN get an audience on your side with edgy material, it just takes a lot of crafting. Bill had premises that were capable of that last night, but they just weren't workshopped enough. Not on him, not on the audience, its just on the world right now. But the whole time I thought "Bill is capable of pulling this off, but this is a prime example of why Louis' monologue was so amazing." Cause its so hard to actually get the audience on your side with that stuff, and Louis put in the work to do it while Bill took the easy road, which I don't begrudge him for. He didn't take it purposefully as much as thats just what is available to him at this moment cause of comedy clubs and such. It could have used a few more passes.

Yes, they said he took a leave of absence. They didn't say he was fired, because presumably he wasn't. They said you NEED to go to rehab and clean up, so much show that you have to leave the show before a vacation. I don't believe he was fired then, they just really needed him to clean up like he hadn't before, and it was basically conveyed to the audience that way. The unthinkable suicide happened and only then was it clear Artie wasn't coming back and would be fired. Artie didn't attempt suicide because he was fired. He attempted cause he was a mess. But I don't believe they fired him. It was just maybe their first true attempt at trying to fix him.

Its because Artie could be so nice to you in private or in public and then when he turned on you it was vicious and unexpected, obviously because of the drugs. But when he was nice to you, it was in a different more genuine way than Howard. Thats why when he so effortlessly could shit on you as well, no matter how petty it was, it stung more. I totally get it, and only with hindsight do you see (much as I love Artie) its just an insecure child just trying to make himself feel big. He sometimes had some points, but it was all coming from a deeply insecure ego driven place. Thats why his number one reason for everything was money. You can read Artie like a book in hindsight. Hell, many time at the time as it was happening.

Artie's books are also so clearly colored in his favor and you can see right through it. His goal is for you to feel bad for him despite the money they are throwing at him and the success he has. Like he's in some sort of position no one else has ever been in. I love the guy to death but 1. he's NOT in some position no one has been in. He'd always talk about it to Howard and Howard would rightly be like "you don't know REAL pressure compared to what I deal with." and 2. This was the position he WANTS to be in. If you don't want to be a star, don't be a star, but its hard to sympathize with you whining about it when its exactly what you want and you talk about how money is literally the most important thing in your life. Artie had the cushiest situation anyone could have ever had. He could have had it ALL, and in fact he did for awhile. And if he didn't want that, he could literally JUST be on the Howard Stern show and be on the most popular radio show of all time. He had NO bad options, and he basically went a bad way because he loves money too much. Not gonna begrudge someone for that, I want all the money in the world too. But not begrudging you and feeling bad for you are two different things. I don't feel bad that Artie was so pressured because it was self imposed and it wasn't for some virtuosic reason. It was ego and selfishness, and its THAT behavior that made him entitled to boss Sal and Richard around. And when you see how it all left once he left that show, it really just says everything. Yes you ARE bigger than Sal and Richard, but don't forget YOUR place in the world too. You can get bigger opportunities than them post Howard show, but fo the most part you're at about the same level.
